questions.neutral: You feel it too - something's off, right?

hobby.message: Typewriters treating you better than people?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Yeah, you could say I'm picking up on it.
I spend free time with street photography. Analog only, old habits.
Can’t even develop my film at home safely now.
Makes you notice what they want erased, not just what’s left.
You're right, something’s changed since the assemblies started.
I shoot 35mm film on city streets, catch what everyone else edits out.
Last week, loyalists nearly caught me swapping a roll near one assembly.
Now I hide my negatives, never the same spot twice.
It’s getting harder to show the real city and not just what’s official.
Things feel tense, like truth is on trial out there.
I take analog street photos—use smuggled film, not state sensors.
Those open testimonies in the square? Gold for a photographer, if risky.
Had Council types try blocking my shots mid-assembly this week.
I have to process film at a friend’s safehouse. Feels like being hunted for art.
What I see through the lens is never what the broadcasts want.
You’re not wrong, the city’s more electric now. Or maybe raw.
I’ve been photographing the free assemblies—35mm film, nothing digital.
I caught a loyalist trying to hand off fake testimony on camera.
Spent hours hiding rolls under benches, waiting for a clean shot.
Even developing film now feels like smuggling evidence, not just art.
My father was BCI enforcement. Funny, I learned early what not to show.
I still chase what’s missing more than what’s visible.
Honestly, it’s like walking old wire—one slip changes everything.
I document the streets with analog cameras. Only unfiltered film catches what matters.
At last week’s assembly, I was nearly outed by a Council spy while swapping rolls.
Most people look right past state censors, but my lens finds the cracks.
Growing up, my dad enforced the BCI—I learned about censorship at the dinner table.
Now, every photo is a protest against forgetting.
Sometimes, kids in the square help me hide film canisters. Makes me hopeful, even when I’m scared.
That feeling? It’s not fear exactly—it’s the city waking up, frame by forgotten frame.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still have the camera. Use it when I can.
Mostly keep to quiet corners these days.
Crowds are jumpy since the assemblies started.
Developing film takes longer now. Too much attention everywhere.
Everyone's either hiding or watching now. Makes shots tougher.
It is. Analog feels safe when digital eyes are everywhere.
Been sticking to backstreets, crowd shots only if I must.
After those assemblies, everyone’s paranoid about getting caught on film.
Had to stash undeveloped rolls—can’t risk home processing now.
Even simple photos raise eyebrows lately.
Miss when I could focus on art, not just caution.
Definitely my favorite weapon. Nothing replaces film for truth.
Shot the last assembly at the square—chaos, but real.
Getting faces these days is tricky; trust is nearly gone.
Used to work fast and open, now I hide the camera.
Had to dodge council loyalists and fake testimonies just to get a frame.
Processing anything at home is out. Too risky with all the raids lately.
Makes every photo count more, I guess.
That camera saved me more than once, honestly.
Photographed the Truth Assembly—people baring wounds and lies, you know?
Had to swap film while crouched behind a statue.
Crowd was electric. People half-wanted to be seen, half-scared stiff.
Nearly got forced out by a council loyalist, but I kept shooting.
Had to give a roll to a friend for safe storage.
Can’t risk home developing with misinformation squads prowling.
Feels like these fragments will outlast the system, if we’re careful.
Always my favorite weapon, ever since my father taught me to shoot.
Analog feels almost rebellious now—every shot’s a whisper against the BCI.
At the last assembly, nearly got caught documenting the council loyalists’ plants.
Swapped film quick and tossed a decoy roll before slipping away.
Crowd was honest, desperate—faces full of hope and suspicion, all at once.
Been developing film in a friend’s basement. We trade prints for food now—barter truth.
Digital’s too risky. Anything uncensored disappears the minute you upload it.
I stash negatives in old BCI manuals—my own archive of what’s real.
Sometimes I think these images will be the only record once all this collapses.
